q: What command initializes a new Git repository?
What does `git status` show?

o: Stages all changes in the current directory

What does `git log --oneline` display?

q: What is a commit in Git?
o: A snapshot of your repository at a specific point in time

Which command displays who changed each line of a file?

o: A pointer to the current branch reference

q: What command shows the content of a specific commit?

What happens if you run `git init` in an existing repository?
o: It safely reinitializes without deleting data

q: What does `git add -p` do?

What is the working directory in Git?
o: The directory where you edit files

q: What command undoes the last commit but keeps changes staged?

What is tracked file in Git?
o: A file that Git is monitoring for changes
A file in the staging area

What does `git status` show as 'untracked'?

o: A unique SHA-1 identifier for each commit

o: Stages only modified and deleted files

q: What is an untracked file?
o: A file not yet added to Git

q: Which command displays the author and date of each commit?

o: Filter commits after a specific date
Show commits since the last push

q: What is the staging area also called?
Which command shows the remote URLs configured for the repository?
What does `git diff --staged` show?
o: Differences between staged changes and last commit

q: What command creates an empty Git repository in a new directory?
What happens when you add a file that is already staged?
o: The staging area is updated with new changes

q: What does `git log --author` filter?
Which level of Git config has the highest priority?
What does `git init --bare` create?
o: A repository without a working directory

q: What command shows files that will be committed?
What is the purpose of `git log --stat`?
o: Shows statistics of files changed in each commit

q: Which command removes a file from both the working directory and staging area?
What does `git commit -v` do?
o: Opens editor showing diff of staged changes

q: What is the purpose of `.gitignore`?
o: To specify files Git should not track

q: Which command sets your Git email?
What does `git log --pretty=format` allow?
What is a bare repository?
o: A repository without a working tree

q: Which command shows the Git version installed?
What does the `--global` flag do in `git config`?

Applies to the current repository only

q: What command shows help for a specific Git command?
What does `git status -b` show?
o: Branch tracking information in short format

q: Which option with `git add` shows what would be added without adding?
What is the default editor for Git commit messages?
o: The system default or configured editor

q: What does `git log --decorate` show?
o: Branch and tag names alongside commits

q: Which command initializes Git and creates an initial commit?
o: There is no single command; git init then git commit

q: What does `git diff HEAD` show?
o: Changes in working directory compared to last commit

q: What is a commit message?
o: A description of the changes in a commit

q: Which command shows commits that changed a specific file?
What does `git add --intent-to-add` do?
o: Records the path will be added later

What does `git log --follow` do?

o: Sets the default text editor for Git

o: All non-hidden files in current directory

What does `git log --grep` filter?

What does `git ls-files` show?
What is the purpose of `git hash-object`?
o: Computes and returns the hash of an object

o: Number and size of loose objects

q: What is the purpose of `git fsck`?
What does the `--cached` flag mean in Git diff?
o: Same as --staged; compares index to last commit

q: What does `git rev-parse HEAD` return?

What does `git log --until` filter?
Which command lists all aliases configured in Git?
What does `git rm --cached` do?
o: Removes file from staging only, keeps working copy

q: How do you create a Git alias?
What is the difference between `git add .` and `git add -A`?
o: git add -A includes deletions from root, git add . is relative to current directory

q: What does `git for-each-ref` do?

q: What does `git log --source` show?

o: Returns non-zero exit code if there are differences

o: --skip-worktree is for user-intentional changes, --assume-unchanged is for performance

What does `git replace` do?

What is the purpose of `git send-email`?

o: Patch files suitable for email submission

q: How do you apply a patch created by `git format-patch`?
What is the difference between `git apply` and `git am`?
o: git am creates commits, git apply just applies changes

q: What does `git filter-branch` do?

q: Which modern replacement for `git filter-branch` is recommended?
What does `git instaweb` do?

q: How do you create a shallow clone?
What limitation does a shallow clone have?
o: Limited history depth, some operations may fail

q: How do you convert a shallow clone to a full clone?

How does `git prune` differ from `git gc`?

q: What does `git count-objects -v` show?

o: Use ! prefix: git config alias.name '!shell command'

q: What are Git trailers?
o: Key-value pairs at end of commit messages like Signed-off-by

q: How do you sign a commit with GPG?
What does `git verify-commit` do?
o: Verifies the GPG signature of a commit

q: How do you configure Git to always sign tags?
What does `git whatchanged` show?
How is `git whatchanged` different from `git log`?
o: whatchanged shows diff output by default; mostly equivalent

q: What does `git range-diff` compare?
o: Two commit ranges to show how patches evolved

q: When is `git range-diff` particularly useful?
o: After rebasing to see how commits changed

How do you find all commits that touched a specific function?
What does `git log -S 'text'` do?
o: Finds commits that added or removed the text

q: How does `git log -G 'regex'` differ from `-S`?
o: -G finds commits where diff matches regex, -S counts occurrences

How do you view a file from a specific commit without checking out?
What does `git checkout -b <branch> <remote>/<branch>` do?
o: Creates local branch tracking the remote branch

q: How do you configure Git to rebase by default on pull?
What does `git pull --ff-only` do?
o: Only pulls if a fast-forward merge is possible

q: What happens with `git merge --no-ff`?
o: Creates a merge commit even if fast-forward is possible

q: What does `git fetch --prune` do?
o: Removes remote tracking refs that no longer exist on remote

q: How do you configure automatic pruning on fetch?
What does `git push --force-with-lease` do?
o: Force pushes only if remote matches expected state

q: Why is `--force-with-lease` safer than `--force`?
o: It fails if others have pushed changes you have not seen

q: What does `git symbolic-ref` create or modify?
o: Symbolic references that point to other refs

q: What is stored in `.git/packed-refs`?

What does `git multi-pack-index` optimize?
What is the commit-graph file used for?
o: Speeds up commit graph traversal operations

What does `git sparse-checkout` allow?

What does `git sparse-checkout set` do?
o: Specifies which paths to include in the sparse checkout

q: What is a partial clone in Git?

q: How do you create a blobless clone?

o: Faster clone by downloading blobs on demand

q: What does `git credential-cache` do?

What does `git credential-store` do?
o: Stores credentials in a plaintext file

q: Why is `credential-store` less secure?
o: Credentials are stored in plaintext on disk

q: What does `git diff --patience` use?

q: What does `git diff --histogram` provide?
o: Histogram diff algorithm, often faster than patience

q: How do you set a default diff algorithm?

o: Commits that are both ancestors of B and descendants of A

q: How do you find the common ancestor of three branches?
What does `git merge-base --fork-point` find?
o: Where a branch forked from another using reflog

q: What is a grafts file in Git?
o: Legacy file to fake commit ancestry, now replaced by git replace

q: What does `git show-index` do?
o: Reads a pack index file and shows its contents

q: How do you verify a pack file?
What does `git index-pack` do?
o: Creates pack index from a pack file

q: What is the difference between annotated and lightweight tags?
o: Annotated tags store metadata including tagger, date, message; lightweight are just pointers

q: How do you list only annotated tags?
o: git tag -l --sort=-taggerdate or check with git cat-file -t

q: What does `git tag -v` do?
o: Verifies the GPG signature of the tag

q: How do you delete a remote tag?
o: git push origin :refs/tags/<tagname> or git push --delete origin <tagname>

q: What does `git push --follow-tags` do?
o: Pushes annotated tags that are reachable from pushed commits

q: How do you configure Git to always follow tags on push?
What does `git check-ref-format` validate?
o: Whether a reference name is valid

q: What characters are not allowed in Git branch names?
o: Space, tilde, caret, colon, question mark, asterisk, backslash, and others

q: What does `git branch --sort=-committerdate` show?
o: Branches sorted by most recent commit first

q: How do you set a default sort order for branches?
What does `git branch -vv` show?
o: Branches with their upstream tracking info and verbose details

q: How do you set the upstream branch for an existing branch?
o: git branch -u origin/branch or git branch --set-upstream-to

q: What does `git branch --no-merged` show?
o: Branches that have not been merged into the current branch

q: How do you rename a remote branch?
o: Push new name, delete old: git push origin new_name; git push origin :old_name

q: What does `git cherry` show?
o: Commits in current branch not in upstream, marked with +/-

q: How do you configure color output in Git?
What does `git config color.status.changed` set?
o: Color for changed files in status output

q: How do you view the effective configuration for a specific key?
What does `git config --show-scope` display?
o: Shows which scope each config value comes from

q: How do you edit the global Git config in an editor?
What is the purpose of `git config include.path`?
How do you use conditional includes in Git config?
What does `git help -a` show?
How do you recover a commit that was garbage collected?
o: You cannot; once GC runs, unreferenced objects are permanently deleted

q: What does `git fsck --dangling` specifically detect?
o: Objects not reachable from any ref but not yet pruned

q: How does Git handle large binary files inefficiently?
o: Stores complete copy of each version, no delta compression for binaries

q: What is Git LFS used for?
o: Managing large files by storing pointers in Git and files externally

q: How does `git lfs track` work?
o: Adds patterns to .gitattributes to mark files for LFS

q: What happens during `git lfs pull`?
o: Downloads actual file contents for LFS pointers

q: What is the purpose of `git diff --binary`?
o: Outputs binary diff in a format that can be applied

q: How do you create an octopus merge?
o: git merge branch1 branch2 branch3... (merging more than two branches)

q: What limitation does octopus merge have?
o: Cannot handle conflicts; fails if any arise

q: What does `git merge -s ours` do?
o: Performs merge but completely ignores changes from other branch

q: How does `git merge -X ours` differ from `-s ours`?
o: -X ours resolves conflicts using our version, -s ours ignores their changes entirely

q: What does `git merge --squash` do?
o: Prepares a single commit with all merged changes, does not create merge commit

q: What does `git subtree` allow?
o: Merging and splitting subdirectories with their own history

q: How does `git subtree` differ from submodules?
o: Subtree merges content into main repo; submodules keep separate repos

q: What does `git subtree add` do?
o: Adds a repository as a subdirectory with full history

q: What is `git stash push -p` used for?
How do you stash untracked files?
What does `git stash --keep-index` do?
o: Stashes unstaged changes but keeps staged changes in index

q: How do you apply a stash without removing it from stash list?
What does `git stash drop` do?
How do you create a branch from a stash?
What does `git clean -x` do?
o: Removes untracked files including those ignored by .gitignore

q: How does `git clean -X` differ from `-x`?
o: -X removes only ignored files, -x removes all untracked including ignored

q: What does `git checkout --orphan` create?
o: A new branch with no commit history

q: When would you use an orphan branch?
o: For completely separate history like gh-pages or documentation

q: What does `git rebase --onto` allow?
o: Rebasing commits onto a different base than the original parent

q: How do you use `git rebase --onto A B C`?
o: Replays commits from B to C onto A
Moves A to B then C
Applies A onto B and C

q: What does `git rebase -i` allow you to do?
o: Interactively reorder, squash, edit, or drop commits

q: What does the 'fixup' command in interactive rebase do?
o: Squashes commit and discards its message

q: What does the 'edit' command in interactive rebase do?
o: Pauses rebase to allow editing the commit

q: How do you split a commit during interactive rebase?
o: Use edit, then reset HEAD~, stage and commit separately, then continue

q: What does `git rebase --autosquash` do?
o: Automatically orders fixup! and squash! commits appropriately

q: How do you prepare a commit for autosquash?
What does `git rebase --exec` do?
o: Runs a command after each rebased commit

q: What is the purpose of `git notes add`?
o: Adds a note to a commit without changing the commit

q: How are git notes stored?
o: In refs/notes/commits, separate from the commit object

q: What does `git notes show` display?
o: The note associated with a commit

q: How do you push notes to a remote?
What does `git blame -w` do?
What does `git blame -M` option enable?
o: Detects lines moved within a file

q: What does `git blame -C -C -C` do?
o: Most aggressive detection of lines copied from any file

q: What is a Git hook?
o: A script triggered by specific Git events

q: Where are client-side hooks stored?
How do you share hooks across a team?
o: Store in repo and configure core.hooksPath, or symlink

q: What does the pre-commit hook do?
o: Runs before commit, can abort if non-zero exit

q: How do you skip a pre-commit hook?
What does the commit-msg hook receive?
o: Path to file containing commit message

q: What is the purpose of prepare-commit-msg hook?
o: Prepares default message before editor opens

q: What does the post-commit hook do?
o: Runs after commit is created, used for notifications

q: What triggers the pre-push hook?
o: Runs before push, receives remote info via stdin

q: What does the post-merge hook do?
o: Runs after a merge, often used to restore permissions

q: What is the pre-rebase hook used for?
o: Prevents rebase on certain branches like master

q: How does the update hook differ from pre-receive?
o: Update runs once per ref, pre-receive once per push

q: What does the post-receive hook do?
o: Runs after all refs updated, used for CI triggers

q: What is `git worktree` useful for?
o: Working on multiple branches simultaneously in separate directories

q: How do you create a new worktree?
What happens if you try to checkout the same branch in two worktrees?
o: Git prevents it to avoid conflicts

q: How do you remove a worktree?
What does `git worktree list` show?
o: All worktrees with their paths and checked out branches

q: What is `git bisect` used for?
o: Binary search through commits to find bug introduction

q: How do you start a bisect session?
What do `git bisect good` and `git bisect bad` do?
o: Mark current commit as working or broken to guide binary search

q: What does `git bisect reset` do?
o: Ends bisect session and returns to original HEAD

q: How do you automate a bisect with a test script?
What does `git bisect skip` do?
o: Skips a commit that cannot be tested

q: What does `git bisect log` output?
o: The commands that led to the current bisect state

q: What does `git cherry-pick` do?
o: Applies a commit from another branch as a new commit

q: What happens if a cherry-pick has conflicts?
o: Git pauses for manual resolution, then continue with --continue

q: How do you cherry-pick multiple commits?
o: git cherry-pick <commit1> <commit2> or git cherry-pick A..B

q: What does `git cherry-pick -x` add?
o: Appends cherry-pick source info to commit message

q: What does `git cherry-pick --no-commit` do?
o: Applies changes without committing, allows combining picks

q: What is `git revert` used for?
o: Creates a new commit that undoes changes from a previous commit

q: How does revert differ from reset?
o: Revert creates new commit preserving history, reset modifies history

q: What does `git revert -m 1` specify?
o: Which parent to use when reverting a merge commit

q: How do you revert multiple commits in one operation?
What is `git reflog expire` used for?
o: Prunes old reflog entries based on age

q: How long are reflog entries kept by default?
o: 90 days for reachable, 30 days for unreachable commits

q: What does `git reflog delete` do?
How do you recover a deleted branch using reflog?
o: Find commit in reflog, then git branch <name> <commit>

q: What does HEAD@{n} notation mean?
o: The nth previous position of HEAD in the reflog

q: What does `git show HEAD@{1}` show?
o: What HEAD was pointing to before the last operation

q: What is branch@{yesterday} syntax used for?
o: Refers to where the branch was at that time using reflog

q: What does `git diff @{upstream}` compare?
o: Current branch against its upstream tracking branch

q: What does `git diff @{push}` compare?
o: Current branch against where it would be pushed

q: What is the purpose of `git request-pull`?
o: Generates a summary for requesting someone to pull from your repo

q: What does `git request-pull` output contain?
o: URL, commit range, and summary suitable for email

q: What is `git daemon` used for?
What does `--export-all` flag do for git daemon?
o: Exports all repositories without needing git-daemon-export-ok file

q: What is the purpose of `git-http-backend`?
o: CGI program for serving repositories over HTTP

q: How do you create a mirror clone?
What does a mirror clone include that a bare clone might not?
o: All refs including remote tracking branches and notes

q: How do you update a mirror?
o: git remote update or git fetch --all

q: What does `git bundle create` produce?
o: A single file containing specified refs and their history

q: How do you verify a bundle before using it?
How do you clone from a bundle?
What is the internal structure of a Git commit object?
o: Tree hash, parent hash(es), author, committer, message

q: How does Git store a tree object internally?
o: Mode, type, hash, and filename for each entry

q: What compression algorithm does Git use for objects?
How are Git object file names derived?
o: SHA-1 hash of type + size + content with first 2 chars as directory

q: What is a packfile in Git?
o: Collection of objects stored efficiently with delta compression

q: How does delta compression work in packfiles?
o: Stores differences between similar objects to save space

q: What does the pack index (.idx) file contain?
o: Sorted object hashes with offsets into the pack file

q: How does `git gc --prune=now` differ from regular gc?
o: Immediately prunes unreachable objects instead of waiting

q: What is the purpose of the .keep file in pack directories?
o: Prevents gc from deleting the pack file

q: What does `git repack -a -d` accomplish?
o: Repacks all objects into one pack and deletes old packs

q: What is a thin pack in Git?
o: Pack with deltas against objects not in the pack, used in transfers

q: How does Git handle symbolic links?
o: Stores the link target as blob content with mode 120000

q: What does mode 100644 represent in Git?
What does mode 100755 represent in Git?
What is the purpose of `git check-mailmap`?
o: Maps author names and emails using .mailmap file

q: What does the .mailmap file do?
o: Canonicalizes author names and emails for display

q: What is `git fast-import` used for?
o: Importing data into Git from a custom format stream

q: What is `git fast-export` used for?
o: Exporting repository data in fast-import format

q: How do you combine fast-export and fast-import?
o: Pipe between them: git fast-export | git fast-import

q: What does `git show-ref --heads` display?
What does `git show-ref --tags` display?
What is the purpose of `git pack-refs`?
What does `git symbolic-ref HEAD` typically contain?
When is HEAD a 'detached HEAD'?
o: When pointing directly to a commit instead of a branch

q: What does `git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD` return?
How do you check if HEAD is detached?
o: git symbolic-ref HEAD will fail with error if detached

q: What is the purpose of ORIG_HEAD?
o: Stores HEAD position before dangerous operations like merge/rebase

q: What is MERGE_HEAD used for?
o: Stores commit being merged during a merge operation

q: What is CHERRY_PICK_HEAD used for?
o: Stores commit being cherry-picked during conflict resolution

q: What is REBASE_HEAD used for?
o: Stores commit being rebased during pause or conflict

q: What does FETCH_HEAD contain after a fetch?
o: The tip of fetched branches with their remote tracking info

q: What is the purpose of `git update-server-info`?
o: Updates auxiliary files for dumb HTTP transport

q: What are the files created by update-server-info?
What is the difference between smart and dumb HTTP transport?
o: Smart uses git-http-backend for efficient transfers; dumb serves static files

q: How does Git determine merge strategy automatically?
o: Based on number of branches; recursive for 2, octopus for more

q: What is the 'recursive' merge strategy?
o: Default for two heads, handles criss-cross merges

q: What is the 'resolve' merge strategy?
o: Simple three-way merge, cannot handle criss-cross

q: What is the 'subtree' merge strategy?
o: Adjusts trees for subtree relationship during merge

q: What does `git merge --strategy-option=patience` do?
o: Uses patience diff algorithm during merge

q: What is `core.autocrlf` setting used for?
o: Handles line ending conversions between platforms

q: What does `core.autocrlf=true` do on Windows?
o: Converts LF to CRLF on checkout, CRLF to LF on commit

q: What does `core.autocrlf=input` do?
o: Converts CRLF to LF on commit, no conversion on checkout

q: What is `core.safecrlf` setting for?
o: Warns or aborts if irreversible CRLF conversion would occur

q: What does `text=auto` in .gitattributes mean?
o: Git auto-detects text files and normalizes line endings

q: What does `* -text` in .gitattributes do?
o: Treats all files as binary, no line ending conversion

q: What is `diff=<driver>` in .gitattributes?
o: Specifies custom diff driver for matching files

q: How do you define a custom diff driver?
What does `filter=<name>` in .gitattributes do?
What is the 'clean' filter used for?
o: Transforms content before storing in Git

q: What is the 'smudge' filter used for?
o: Transforms content when checking out from Git

q: What is an example use case for clean/smudge filters?
What does `merge=<driver>` in .gitattributes specify?
o: Custom merge driver for conflict resolution

q: How do you define a custom merge driver?
What does `merge=ours` in .gitattributes mean?
o: Always keep our version during merge conflicts for matching files

q: What is `export-ignore` in .gitattributes?
o: Excludes files from git archive exports

q: What is `export-subst` in .gitattributes?
o: Performs variable substitution in file during git archive

q: What variables can be used with export-subst?
What does `binary` attribute in .gitattributes do?
o: Marks file as binary: no line ending conversion, no diff, no merge

q: What is `linguist-vendored` in .gitattributes?
o: Marks files as vendor code, excluded from GitHub language stats

q: What is `linguist-generated` in .gitattributes?
o: Marks files as generated, excluded from GitHub stats and diffs

q: How does Git handle submodules internally?
o: Stores commit hash in parent tree with mode 160000

q: What does .gitmodules file contain?
o: URL and path mappings for submodules

q: What does `git submodule update --remote` do?
o: Updates submodules to the latest remote commit

q: How do you change a submodule URL?
o: Edit .gitmodules and run git submodule sync

q: What does `git submodule foreach` do?
o: Runs a command in each submodule directory

q: What is the difference between submodule and subtree approaches?
o: Submodule keeps separate repos; subtree merges history into main repo

q: What does `git worktree lock` do?
o: Prevents worktree from being pruned as stale

q: What does `git worktree prune` do?
o: Removes worktree metadata for deleted worktrees

q: What is the `.git` file in a linked worktree?
o: A file containing path to the main repository's .git directory

q: How do you recover from a corrupted index?
o: Delete .git/index and run git reset to recreate it

q: What does `git read-tree` do?
o: Reads tree information into the index

q: What does `git checkout-index` do?
o: Copies files from index to working directory

q: What is three-way merge in Git context?
o: Merge considering common ancestor, our version, and their version

q: What are conflict markers in Git?
What does diff3 conflict style show additionally?
o: The common ancestor version between our and their markers

q: How do you enable diff3 conflict style?
What does `git ls-files -u` show?
o: Unmerged files with their stage numbers

q: What do stage numbers 1, 2, and 3 represent in conflicts?
How do you view a specific stage of a conflicted file?
What does `git checkout --ours` do during conflict?
What does `git checkout --theirs` do during conflict?
What is `git mergetool` used for?
o: Launches configured merge tool to resolve conflicts

q: How do you abort a merge in progress?
How do you continue a merge after resolving conflicts?
o: git add resolved files then git commit or git merge --continue

q: What does `git rerere` stand for?
How does rerere help with rebasing?
o: Automatically applies previously recorded conflict resolutions

q: What does `git rerere forget` do?
o: Removes recorded resolution for a file

q: What is the purpose of shallow submodules?
o: Clone submodules with limited depth to save space and time

q: How do you clone with shallow submodules?
What does `git submodule absorbgitdirs` do?
o: Moves submodule .git directories into the superproject's .git/modules

q: What is the purpose of `git submodule set-url`?
o: Updates the URL for a submodule in .gitmodules

q: What does `gc.auto` configuration control?
o: Number of loose objects before auto-gc triggers

q: What does `gc.autoPackLimit` control?
o: Number of packs before auto-gc repacks

q: What is the purpose of `git maintenance prefetch`?
o: Fetches from remotes in background for faster future fetches

q: What does `git maintenance loose-objects` task do?
What is scalar in the Git ecosystem?
o: Tool for managing very large Git repositories efficiently

q: What features does scalar enable by default?
o: Sparse checkout, partial clone, file system monitor, maintenance

q: What is FSMonitor in Git?
o: File system monitor integration for faster status operations

q: How does FSMonitor improve performance?
o: Tracks file changes via OS, avoiding full directory scans

q: What does `core.fsmonitor` configuration control?
o: Enables file system monitor with optional hook command

q: What is the purpose of `git commit-graph verify`?
o: Verifies the integrity of the commit-graph file

q: What does `git multi-pack-index write` create?
o: A MIDX file for efficient lookups across pack files

q: What is the purpose of `git maintenance gc`?
o: Runs garbage collection as part of maintenance schedule

q: What does `core.untrackedCache` enable?
o: Caches untracked file information for faster status

q: What is the split index feature in Git?
o: Splits index into shared and extension parts for faster updates

q: How do you enable split index?
What does `GIT_TRACE=1` environment variable enable?
o: Outputs trace information about Git operations

q: What does `GIT_TRACE_PERFORMANCE=1` show?
What is the purpose of `GIT_SSH_COMMAND` environment variable?
o: Specifies the SSH command used for remote operations

q: What does `git credential fill` do?
o: Gets credentials from the credential helper

q: What does `git credential approve` do?
o: Tells the credential helper to store the given credential

q: What does `git credential reject` do?
o: Tells the credential helper to erase the stored credential

q: What is the purpose of `git bugreport`?
o: Generates a bug report with system and Git information

q: What does `git diagnose` produce?
o: A zip file with diagnostic information about the repository

q: What is the purpose of `git version --build-options`?
